Introducing Wizzy ‚Äî a surveillance and patrolling robot I developed as part of my Tinker Lab project, designed to work in environments where traditional CCTV systems fall short.Wizzy is more than just a mobile bot. It‚Äôs a self-thinking, self-correcting system powered by a Raspberry Pi 4 ‚Äî capable of intelligent patrolling, real-time decision-making, and remote monitoring. Built with flexibility and scalability in mind, Wizzy is ideal for warehouses, mid-sized factories, or secure zones where both movement and memory matter.What makes Wizzy tick:1) Smart Patrol System: Avoids getting stuck, detects patterns, and makes decisions based on sensor input2) Memory of previous states and paths: Reduces repeated loops and improves efficiency over time3) Remote Surveillance: Includes a web dashboard for manual control and camera feed access4) Real-time camera monitoring: Captures and transmits visual data during patrol5) Modular codebase: Clean Python code with multithreading and behavior modelingUnder the hood: Wizzy‚Äôs core logic is written in Python, using multithreading for non-blocking patrol control. The SmartPatrol engine implements a stateful decision system ‚Äî analyzing IR sensor inputs to detect obstacles, identify stuck loops, and dynamically choose optimal turn directions. It uses pattern history (via deques), state memory, and an adaptive escape mechanism to enhance area coverage. Motion control, decision branches, and environmental feedback are abstracted for flexibility and reusability.The entire project is open-source and available here: üîó https://lnkd.in/dY4KyM3BThis started as a college submission ‚Äî but I see it as the first step toward practical, deployable surveillance robotics.hashtag#Robotics hashtag#Automation hashtag#Surveillance hashtag#RaspberryPi hashtag#PythonProjects hashtag#CollegeProjects hashtag#SmartSecurity hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#WizzyBot hashtag#OpenSource

Here's my latest JavaFX project. The famous card game locally known as 'Daketti'.After often playing with friends till late night, I thought why not code it?Here's are its main features‚û°Ô∏èPlayed between four players with two in each team.‚û°Ô∏èGame starts with 4 cards in hand of each player and 4 cards in center.‚û°Ô∏èExcessive use of List and Stack data structures.‚û°Ô∏èJavaFX Transition classes for animation.‚û°Ô∏èUse of OOP principles for a scalable structure.‚û°Ô∏èGame result calculation in the end.Currently it is played on a single PC. Future plans are to make it playable on LAN on 4 PC's using java socket programming. Also the code design focuses on all 4 OOP principles, so I have a plan to add some other card games in the collection like (local names) 'Thula', 'Bluff', etc.

Well-designed APIs behave consistently, fair predictably, and grow without friction. Some best practices to keep in mind are as follows:1 - Resource-oriented paths and proper use of HTTP verbs help APIs align with standard tools.2 - Use a proper API versioning approach.3 - Use standard error codes while generating API responses.4 - APIs should be idempotent. They ensure safe retries by making repeated requests to produce the same result, especially for POST operations.5 - Idempotency keys allow clients to safely deduplicate operations with side effects.6 - APIs should support pagination to prevent performance bottlenecks and payload bloat. Some common pagination strategies are offset-based, cursor-based, and keyset-based.7 - API security is mandatory for well-designed APIs. Use proper authentication and authorization with APIs using API Keys, JWTs, OAuth2, and other mechanisms. HTTPS is also a must-have for APIs running in production.

Ouzo-Driven Innovation: Rethinking Transformation on the Shores of Crete(Long Polish May weekend parody post ;) )As global leaders debate AI ethics and supply chain resilience, a quiet but powerful shift is happening under the Mediterranean sun. Here on Crete, I‚Äôve spent the last few days deep-diving into a radically decentralized, ouzo-fueled innovation ecosystem ‚Äî and the insights are staggering.This island isn‚Äôt just a vacation spot. It‚Äôs a next-gen sandbox for sun-powered cognitive agility. Every taverna is a use case. Every glass of ouzo? A local MVP (Minimum Viable Productivity).Key takeaways from the Cretan Tech Stack:‚û°Ô∏èLiquid-Led Ideation: Traditional brainstorming is out. ‚ÄúOuzoStorming‚Ñ¢‚Äù encourages asynchronous ideation supported by grilled squid and ambient goat sounds.‚û°Ô∏èDecentralized Agility: Herding cats? Try herding donkeys through olive groves. The agile metaphor is alive and braying.‚û°Ô∏èZorba-as-a-Service (ZaaS): Local dance-based leadership rituals now drive team cohesion and real-time alignment, measured in BPM (Beats per Minute).‚û°Ô∏èRelax-to-Earn Infrastructure: Blockchain-enhanced beach chairs allow for staking your towel and generating ‚ÄúPassive Leisure Yield.‚Äù Optional NFT upgrade includes a frappe.‚û°Ô∏èEmbedded UX Rituals: Every strategic lunch concludes with unsolicited raki and dessert ‚Äî a UX feature that transforms customer journeys into literal sugar rushes.‚û°Ô∏èAmbient Feline Monitoring (AFM): Strategic feline deployment (i.e. street cats) ensures continuous surveillance of sidewalk sentiment and supports natural pest control in legacy systems.‚û°Ô∏èWisdom-as-a-Platform (WaaP): Elderly Greek men form decentralized knowledge hubs (a.k.a. kafeneio clusters), delivering continuous, unfiltered socio-political commentary in analog format, with optional smoke signal outputs.‚û°Ô∏èFarm-to-Framework Cuisine: Local KPIs include ‚ÄúDaily Freshness Index,‚Äù measured in tomato juiciness and feta salinity. Culinary ops are lean, green, and olive-oil optimized.Crete isn‚Äôt just following trends ‚Äî it‚Äôs disrupting disruption itself. For anyone in BSS, FDI, AI, ESG, DEI, BYOB or just REST ‚Äî this island is a must-watch.More insights to follow...after my next raki.hashtag#crete hashtag#greece hashtag#weekend hashtag#parody

hashtag#Day11_of_learning with BOLUWATIFE ASOKERE Day 11 was all about understanding how to structure API requests. Here‚Äôs a clear breakdown of what I learned:1. API Endpoint  This is the main URL where the request is sent. It follows the format: `baseURL/Endpoint` (e.g.http://api.example.com/users).2. Path Parameters These are used to specify a particular resource. The format is: `baseURL/Endpoint/{path-parameter}` (e.g., https://api.example.comq/users/123). For example, "123" identifies a specific user.3. Query Parameters These are used to filter or sort data. The format is: `baseURL/Endpoint?query=value` hashtag#30days_of_learninghashtag#APIs

Our newest study on "Managerial practices shaping the transformation towards artificial intelligence-enabled product‚Äìservice systems" is out as hashtag#OpenAccessSome highlights:1. Focus on Digital Servitization and AI:¬†The research highlights the significance of digital service innovation within manufacturing and the need to understand the pathways for transitioning to AI-enabled PSS, given the rapid advancement of AI technologies.2. Identification of Managerial Practices:¬†the study investigates and identifies essential managerial practices, such as strategizing, evangelizing, and routinizing, required during different phases (preparing, conceptualizing, industrializing) of the transformation towards AI-enabled PSS, utilizing practice theory.3. Development of a Multi-Layered Path Model:¬†The study proposes a model illustrating the interconnectedness of AI-enabled PSS, the associated technologies, and crucial ecosystem partnerships needed for a successful transformation.4. Key Case Study Insights:¬†Findings from a case study emphasize the critical need for developing a robust digital infrastructure, integrating established system technologies, industrializing AI capabilities, and fostering ecosystem partnerships to create effective AI-enabled PSS.5. Evolutionary Process Framework:¬†The research presents a process framework detailing the three phases of transformation (preparing, conceptualizing, industrializing) and shows how managerial practices and AI-enabled PSS evolve and interact throughout this journey.6. Theoretical Contributions:¬†The study advances the digital servitization literature by incorporating AI into PSS frameworks, defining specific managerial practices for AI implementation, and outlining a path model critical for manufacturers moving towards autonomous solutions.Many thanks to my great co-authors, Thomas Brekke, Rimsha Naeem, David Sj√∂din, and Vinit Parida, for co-creating this piece. Also, many thanks to the reviewers, special Issue editors, and International Journal of Production Economics.hashtag#ArtificialIntelligence hashtag#AI hashtag#servitization hashtag#servitization hashtag#PSS hashtag#BusinessModel hashtag#AutonomousSolutionsUniversity of Vaasa Strategic Business Development Research Group (SBD), University of Vaasa

Working with watchdog timers in RTOS systems brings interesting challenges.The basic idea is simple: the watchdog counts down and resets the system if it‚Äôs not reloaded in time useful to detect infinite loops or system hangs.But in multitask systems with different deadlines (e.g., one task running every 10ms, another every 100ms), feeding the watchdog from each task becomes unreliable and messy (due to timing and concurrency issues).Some alternatives I‚Äôve explored: - Idle-priority task feeding: Since the feeder task has the lowest priority, if any higher-priority task hangs, the watchdog won‚Äôt be fed and will eventually reset the system. - Task notification system: Each task sends an ‚ÄúI‚Äôm alive‚Äù signal to a watchdog monitor. If one fails, you can react more precisely, like restart only the faulty task if a full system reset isn‚Äôt necessary.While reading the hashtag#ZephyrRTOS docs, i've found a great solution called Task Watchdog:It uses kernel software timers to monitor tasks and can trigger custom callback functions when a task fails to reset its own timer. We can define per-task deadlines and recovery behavior, and still fall back to the hardware watchdog if needed.I might try this feature in my Zephyr-based cruise control system if I get the time, and if so, I‚Äôll share some of the results.

Force Majeure: Back-to-Back relevanceIn interconnected contracts, especially where you (as seller) are the intermediary, mismatched Force Majeure ("FM") clauses can leave you exposed. If your supplier is excused from performance due to an FM event, but your contract with the buyer doesn‚Äôt recognise the same event or relief, you could be held liable. The same applies if your buyer is excused from performance due to an FM event, but your contract with the seller does not recognise the same event. Why Back-to-Back FM Clauses Are Essential: 1. Risk Transfer Protection:‚Ä¢ If a supplier invokes FM to delay or cancel delivery, the seller must also have the right to invoke FM with the buyer.‚Ä¢ Without a back-to-back clause, the intermediary could still be liable to the buyer despite being unable to receive the goods from the supplier.Please note, this could apply similarly where the buyer invokes an FM event, where the intermediary would be liable to the supplier.2. Consistency in Legal Relief‚Ä¢ Ensures both contracts excuse performance for the same types of unforeseen events (e.g., war, natural disasters, strikes).‚Ä¢ Misalignment could result in one party being relieved while the other remains legally bound.3. Avoiding Commercial Gaps‚Ä¢ For example, if the purchase contract includes pandemics as an FM event but the sale contract does not, the intermediary could be stuck with an unfulfillable obligation and no legal shield.4. Aligned Notice Requirements‚Ä¢ Both contracts should include the same timing and method for notifying FM events.‚Ä¢ If the supplier has 48 hours to notify but the buyer requires notice within 24 hours, the intermediary could lose the right to claim FM downstream.5. Termination Triggers‚Ä¢ Many contracts allow termination if the FM persists beyond a certain period (e.g., 30 days).‚Ä¢ Back-to-back durations are essential to avoid mismatched termination rights and prevent being forced into or out of a deal unfairly.Example:A trader buys steel coils from a mill in China under a contract with an FM clause that includes ‚Äúnatural disasters.‚Äù He sells to a European buyer under a contract without an FM clause, or without the FM clause including natural disasters as an FM event. If Chinese ports close due to an earthquake:‚Ä¢ The supplier is excused from delivery.‚Ä¢ The trader is still bound to deliver to the buyer or pay damages‚Äîunless the FM clause is mirrored.Conclusion:In trading and supply chain transactions, back-to-back Force Majeure clauses are not just legal formalities or boilerplate‚Äîthey‚Äôre critical risk management tools. They ensure that when one party is excused from performance, the intermediary is not left exposed to penalties, claims, or losses from the other party.

Java 24 just dropped, and I took some of my saturday to dig into the changes compared to Java 23... And I have to say, it‚Äôs a solid update. One of the things I was really looking forward to was the finalization of the Foreign Function & Memory API, it basically gives Java a safe, high-performance way to interact with native code and memory, without all the clunky, error creator boilerplate of JNI. You can now allocate off-heap memory, call native libraries, and work with memory segments almost like you're in C, but with Java safety.. I also appreciate how Java 24 is going fr preview features, like unnamed variables and patterns, not sure if they are really usefull, but I like previews, lets test it.On the tooling and performance side, the improvements to the JIT compiler and the enhancements to garbage collection are things I started seeing the impact in some memory-heavy workloads. It feels like Java is becoming a more modern language without losing what made it so stable and reliable in the first place. I‚Äôm still cautious about adopting preview features in production, but I like where things are going, it‚Äôs like Java is shaking off some of its old weight while staying rock-solid for enterprise apps. I‚Äôll definitely be using Java 24 for side projects just to explore everything more deeply.Oh, almost forgot to mention, if you wanna test the previews, use this:--enable-preview If you‚Äôre using intelij, like me, you‚Äôll also need to enable preview features in the project settings.

DPDK, eBPF, and XDP: Their Crucial Roles in Virtual NetworkingIn virtual networking, DPDK, eBPF, and XDP each offer distinct advantages for optimizing performance, security, and observability. DPDK excels in high-performance, low-latency packet processing by bypassing the kernel, making it ideal for user-space network functions like virtual switches (OVS-DPDK) and virtual network functions (VNFs), where throughput and customizability are critical. eBPF, running in the kernel, enables efficient network observability, security policy enforcement, and deep packet inspection with minimal overhead. It is often integrated into Kubernetes CNI plugins like Cilium and Calico for network visibility and microsegmentation. XDP, built on top of eBPF, provides ultra-fast ingress filtering by executing programs directly at the NIC driver level, making it ideal for early packet filtering and load balancing, which reduces network congestion and latency in multi-tenant environments. Together, these technologies power modern cloud-native networks, providing high performance, flexible security, and granular control, particularly in virtualized environments like Kubernetes and NFV architectures.1. DPDKIdeal for virtual switches, VNFs, and edge compute gateways.Enables performance similar to hardware appliances.Extensively used in OpenStack and telecom NFV solutions.2. eBPF Powers Cilium, Tetragon, and other Kubernetes CNIs and observability tools.Integrates with Linux namespaces, cgroups, containers, and VMs.Extensible without kernel patches, supporting zero-trust security models.Limited performance vs DPDK in raw throughput.3. XDFIdeal for DDOS mitigation, early firewalling, and L4 load balancing.Reduces load on host networking stack yet important in multi-tenant environments.Limited programmability compared to full eBPF (no loops, tight instruction budget).Widely used in Cilium, Facebook Katran, and cloud CNI pipelines.hashtag#DPDK hashtag#eBPF hashtag#XDP hashtag#Cilium hashtag#Katran hashtag#CNI hashtag#Kubernetes hashtag#Tetragon hashtag#OVS

üöÄ Excited to share my latest serverless project!I built a fully serverless contact form system using AWS Lambda, API Gateway, DynamoDB and SNS, eliminating the need for server management while embracing a scalable and efficient architecture.Here‚Äôs how it works:API Gateway handles form submissionsAWS Lambda processes the logic (Python)DynamoDB stores the form dataSNS sends real-time admin alertsCORS headers enable smooth frontend integrationIAM roles ensure secure, least-privilege accessThis project gave me the opportunity to build a flexible, secure, and easily scalable solution using serverless principles.What i learned: * The power of API Gateway in routing and handling form submissions with    ease: API Gateway plays a pivotal role in the entire serverless flow. It handles HTTP requests and routes them to the correct AWS Lambda function, ensuring smooth communication between the frontend and backend. This makes it an essential tool for any serverless application, as it takes care of all the necessary HTTP request and response operations without requiring traditional server management.* How Lambda can simplify backend logic without managing traditional servers:AWS Lambda enables you to run code in response to events without the need to provision or manage servers. In this project, I leveraged Lambda to handle form submissions, which allowed me to focus solely on the logic (written in Python) without worrying about underlying infrastructure. This means no need for instance scaling or server maintenance‚ÄîLambda takes care of the scaling automatically based on the number of requests, making it a powerful tool for lightweight, cost-effective solutions.* The importance of setting up CORS headers properly for seamless integration with frontend applications: Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) is a crucial part of enabling smooth communication between a frontend (e.g., a web application) and a backend API hosted on a different domain. In this project, setting up CORS headers correctly allowed my frontend to make secure and successful API requests to the Lambda functions behind API Gateway. Without proper CORS configuration, you‚Äôd run into errors that would block requests, making the integration process a challenge. Handling CORS properly is essential for serverless architectures to work seamlessly across different domains.üìù Check out the full project walkthrough here:

Is "Consideration" still relevant in Modern Contract Law?ü§î" ÿßŸÑÿπŸÇŸàÿØ ÿßŸÑÿπŸàÿ∂Ÿäÿ© "üëáüèªüëáüèªüëáüèªIn an age of digital transactions, subscription models, and smart contracts, some might wonder: does the Doctrine of Consideration still matter?‚ÅâÔ∏è‚ùì‚ùì‚ùìThe answer is yes ‚úîÔ∏è... and here's why:üëáüèª‚è© The Doctrine of "Consideration" ensures that a contract reflects a mutual exchange. It's not just about promises, it's about value. Whether it's payment for a service, access to software, or even agreeing to refrain from a certain action, consideration creates the legal backbone that makes the agreement enforceable.‚è© Modern contracts may look different such as Clickwrap agreements, Software as a Service (SaaS), and Influencer Brand Deals, but the principle remains: no "Consideration", no binding contract.‚è© Even in jurisdictions exploring contract reform, the idea that both parties must give something to get something remains a key safeguard against unfair or one-sided obligations.‚è© Understanding "Consideration" is essential for legal professionals, founders, and anyone involved in "deal-making" in the digital economy.üé¨ What are your thoughts on how technology is changing the way we handle contracts‚ùì hashtag#ContractLaw hashtag#LegalTech hashtag#DigitalContracts hashtag#ModernLaw hashtag#TechAndLaw hashtag#StartupLaw hashtag#SaaSContracts hashtag#BusinessLaw hashtag#Consideration hashtag#LegalBasicshashtag#ÿßŸÑŸÇÿßŸÜŸàŸÜ hashtag#ÿßŸÑÿπŸÇŸàÿØ hashtag#ÿßŸÑŸÇÿßŸÜŸàŸÜ_ÿßŸÑŸÖÿØŸÜŸä hashtag#ÿßŸÑŸÇÿßŸÜŸàŸÜ_ÿßŸÑÿ™ÿ¨ÿßÿ±Ÿä hashtag#ÿßŸÑÿ™ÿ≠ŸàŸÑ_ÿßŸÑÿ±ŸÇŸÖŸä hashtag#ÿπŸÇŸàÿØ_ÿπŸàÿ∂Ÿäÿ© hashtag#ÿßŸÑÿ∞ŸÉÿßÿ°_ÿßŸÑÿßÿµÿ∑ŸÜÿßÿπŸä_ŸàÿßŸÑŸÇÿßŸÜŸàŸÜ hashtag#ÿ±ŸäÿßÿØÿ©_ÿßŸÑÿ£ÿπŸÖÿßŸÑ_ÿßŸÑŸÇÿßŸÜŸàŸÜŸäÿ© hashtag#ÿßŸÑÿπŸÖŸÑ_ÿßŸÑŸÇÿßŸÜŸàŸÜŸä hashtag#ÿßŸÑŸÇÿßŸÜŸàŸÜ_ŸàÿßŸÑÿ™ŸÉŸÜŸàŸÑŸàÿ¨Ÿäÿßÿ™_ÿßŸÑÿ≠ÿØŸäÿ´ÿ©

A Note to my Fellow General Counsels: Protect Your Business First.I‚Äôve been reviewing a lot of agreements lately and i thought to share this:When reviewing legal agreements, always begin with the end in mind. Assume realistically, that the relationship may deteriorate. Your role is to ensure your organisation is insulated when it does.One of the most critical tools in your arsenal? The termination clause.Scrutinise it. Then scrutinise the clauses that hinge on it; notice periods, payment obligations, survival provisions, dispute mechanisms. These are not boilerplate. They are strategy. Spin it in all ways till you are comfortable with the way it sounds should the relationship breakdown. Insist on the right to terminate without cause. Say it clearly: ‚ÄúWe reserve the right to terminate this agreement at any time, without cause, by providing a 5-day written notice.‚Äù Nothing about your termination clause should be ambiguous or interpreted in a way that can give rise to a different meaning but that which you intended. Any attempt by the counterparty to dilute or eliminate this right should be met with resistance, or at minimum, renegotiated with leverage. If you‚Äôre the party with power, exercise it. If you‚Äôre not, structure flexibility into the agreement early.Termination without cause is not just a fallback. It‚Äôs your legal parachute.ü™Çhashtag#GeneralCounsel hashtag#LegalLeadership hashtag#ExecutiveLeadership.

üß† Deep Dive: From Notification Failure to Protocol Insight ‚Äì Debugging SCTP_SEND_FAILEDIn this post, I walk through a subtle but critical SCTP issue that emerged when handling SCTP_SEND_FAILED notifications ‚Äî exploring how low-level socket events, memory layout, and system-generated notification structures like sctp_send_failed reveal the real root cause behind failed datagram delivery in production.üîç Unpacking SCTP_SEND_FAILED: From Kernel Notification to Root CauseIn SCTP-based communication systems, handling failure gracefully is as critical as achieving successful transmission. This post traces a real-world debugging session triggered by a recurring SCTP_SEND_FAILED notification ‚Äî often dismissed as a low-level socket error, but here unpacked layer by layer to reveal deep transport-level insights.We begin at the point of failure: a datagram silently dropped, triggering a structured SCTP notification. Using sctp_send_failed and its fields (ssf_type, ssf_flags, ssf_error, and ssf_info), we decode the kernel's message about why the send operation couldn't complete. We show how to safely extract this information from a raw notification buffer, interpret the semantics of each field, and map it back to application-layer intent.To go deeper, we captured traffic with Wireshark and discovered a critical clue: a heartbeat message sent from a Docker container to our system, which unexpectedly led to the abortion of the SCTP association. This insight helped correlate the SCTP_SEND_FAILED with external traffic patterns, uncovering the real trigger ‚Äî an out-of-band heartbeat interpreted as a protocol violation or arriving during a teardown state.By analyzing memory handling, buffer reuse, and edge-case protocol behavior (like full receive queues or association termination), we arrived at a concrete cause ‚Äî often buried deep beneath user-facing symptoms. This is a story of system-level observability, correct struct alignment, and mastering the contract between user space and kernel through precise data interpretation.Ideal for engineers working with SCTP, E2AP, or any protocol stack that depends on robust notification handling.I‚Äôd be glad to collaborate on any projects in the fields of telecommunications systems, wireless networks, network protocols, or low-level programming. If you believe my experience and skills can contribute to your work, I‚Äôd be more than happy to be part of your team ‚Äî even in a small role.

Introducing Wizzy ‚Äî a surveillance and patrolling robot I developed as part of my Tinker Lab project, designed to work in environments where traditional CCTV systems fall short.Wizzy is more than just a mobile bot. It‚Äôs a self-thinking, self-correcting system powered by a Raspberry Pi 4 ‚Äî capable of intelligent patrolling, real-time decision-making, and remote monitoring. Built with flexibility and scalability in mind, Wizzy is ideal for warehouses, mid-sized factories, or secure zones where both movement and memory matter.What makes Wizzy tick:1) Smart Patrol System: Avoids getting stuck, detects patterns, and makes decisions based on sensor input2) Memory of previous states and paths: Reduces repeated loops and improves efficiency over time3) Remote Surveillance: Includes a web dashboard for manual control and camera feed access4) Real-time camera monitoring: Captures and transmits visual data during patrol5) Modular codebase: Clean Python code with multithreading and behavior modelingUnder the hood: Wizzy‚Äôs core logic is written in Python, using multithreading for non-blocking patrol control. The SmartPatrol engine implements a stateful decision system ‚Äî analyzing IR sensor inputs to detect obstacles, identify stuck loops, and dynamically choose optimal turn directions. It uses pattern history (via deques), state memory, and an adaptive escape mechanism to enhance area coverage. Motion control, decision branches, and environmental feedback are abstracted for flexibility and reusability.The entire project is open-source and available here: üîó https://lnkd.in/dY4KyM3BThis started as a college submission ‚Äî but I see it as the first step toward practical, deployable surveillance robotics.hashtag#Robotics hashtag#Automation hashtag#Surveillance hashtag#RaspberryPi hashtag#PythonProjects hashtag#CollegeProjects hashtag#SmartSecurity hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#WizzyBot hashtag#OpenSource

Here's my latest JavaFX project. The famous card game locally known as 'Daketti'.After often playing with friends till late night, I thought why not code it?Here's are its main features‚û°Ô∏èPlayed between four players with two in each team.‚û°Ô∏èGame starts with 4 cards in hand of each player and 4 cards in center.‚û°Ô∏èExcessive use of List and Stack data structures.‚û°Ô∏èJavaFX Transition classes for animation.‚û°Ô∏èUse of OOP principles for a scalable structure.‚û°Ô∏èGame result calculation in the end.Currently it is played on a single PC. Future plans are to make it playable on LAN on 4 PC's using java socket programming. Also the code design focuses on all 4 OOP principles, so I have a plan to add some other card games in the collection like (local names) 'Thula', 'Bluff', etc.

Well-designed APIs behave consistently, fair predictably, and grow without friction. Some best practices to keep in mind are as follows:1 - Resource-oriented paths and proper use of HTTP verbs help APIs align with standard tools.2 - Use a proper API versioning approach.3 - Use standard error codes while generating API responses.4 - APIs should be idempotent. They ensure safe retries by making repeated requests to produce the same result, especially for POST operations.5 - Idempotency keys allow clients to safely deduplicate operations with side effects.6 - APIs should support pagination to prevent performance bottlenecks and payload bloat. Some common pagination strategies are offset-based, cursor-based, and keyset-based.7 - API security is mandatory for well-designed APIs. Use proper authentication and authorization with APIs using API Keys, JWTs, OAuth2, and other mechanisms. HTTPS is also a must-have for APIs running in production.

Ouzo-Driven Innovation: Rethinking Transformation on the Shores of Crete(Long Polish May weekend parody post ;) )As global leaders debate AI ethics and supply chain resilience, a quiet but powerful shift is happening under the Mediterranean sun. Here on Crete, I‚Äôve spent the last few days deep-diving into a radically decentralized, ouzo-fueled innovation ecosystem ‚Äî and the insights are staggering.This island isn‚Äôt just a vacation spot. It‚Äôs a next-gen sandbox for sun-powered cognitive agility. Every taverna is a use case. Every glass of ouzo? A local MVP (Minimum Viable Productivity).Key takeaways from the Cretan Tech Stack:‚û°Ô∏èLiquid-Led Ideation: Traditional brainstorming is out. ‚ÄúOuzoStorming‚Ñ¢‚Äù encourages asynchronous ideation supported by grilled squid and ambient goat sounds.‚û°Ô∏èDecentralized Agility: Herding cats? Try herding donkeys through olive groves. The agile metaphor is alive and braying.‚û°Ô∏èZorba-as-a-Service (ZaaS): Local dance-based leadership rituals now drive team cohesion and real-time alignment, measured in BPM (Beats per Minute).‚û°Ô∏èRelax-to-Earn Infrastructure: Blockchain-enhanced beach chairs allow for staking your towel and generating ‚ÄúPassive Leisure Yield.‚Äù Optional NFT upgrade includes a frappe.‚û°Ô∏èEmbedded UX Rituals: Every strategic lunch concludes with unsolicited raki and dessert ‚Äî a UX feature that transforms customer journeys into literal sugar rushes.‚û°Ô∏èAmbient Feline Monitoring (AFM): Strategic feline deployment (i.e. street cats) ensures continuous surveillance of sidewalk sentiment and supports natural pest control in legacy systems.‚û°Ô∏èWisdom-as-a-Platform (WaaP): Elderly Greek men form decentralized knowledge hubs (a.k.a. kafeneio clusters), delivering continuous, unfiltered socio-political commentary in analog format, with optional smoke signal outputs.‚û°Ô∏èFarm-to-Framework Cuisine: Local KPIs include ‚ÄúDaily Freshness Index,‚Äù measured in tomato juiciness and feta salinity. Culinary ops are lean, green, and olive-oil optimized.Crete isn‚Äôt just following trends ‚Äî it‚Äôs disrupting disruption itself. For anyone in BSS, FDI, AI, ESG, DEI, BYOB or just REST ‚Äî this island is a must-watch.More insights to follow...after my next raki.hashtag#crete hashtag#greece hashtag#weekend hashtag#parody

hashtag#Day11_of_learning with BOLUWATIFE ASOKERE Day 11 was all about understanding how to structure API requests. Here‚Äôs a clear breakdown of what I learned:1. API Endpoint  This is the main URL where the request is sent. It follows the format: `baseURL/Endpoint` (e.g.http://api.example.com/users).2. Path Parameters These are used to specify a particular resource. The format is: `baseURL/Endpoint/{path-parameter}` (e.g., https://api.example.comq/users/123). For example, "123" identifies a specific user.3. Query Parameters These are used to filter or sort data. The format is: `baseURL/Endpoint?query=value` hashtag#30days_of_learninghashtag#APIs

Our newest study on "Managerial practices shaping the transformation towards artificial intelligence-enabled product‚Äìservice systems" is out as hashtag#OpenAccessSome highlights:1. Focus on Digital Servitization and AI:¬†The research highlights the significance of digital service innovation within manufacturing and the need to understand the pathways for transitioning to AI-enabled PSS, given the rapid advancement of AI technologies.2. Identification of Managerial Practices:¬†the study investigates and identifies essential managerial practices, such as strategizing, evangelizing, and routinizing, required during different phases (preparing, conceptualizing, industrializing) of the transformation towards AI-enabled PSS, utilizing practice theory.3. Development of a Multi-Layered Path Model:¬†The study proposes a model illustrating the interconnectedness of AI-enabled PSS, the associated technologies, and crucial ecosystem partnerships needed for a successful transformation.4. Key Case Study Insights:¬†Findings from a case study emphasize the critical need for developing a robust digital infrastructure, integrating established system technologies, industrializing AI capabilities, and fostering ecosystem partnerships to create effective AI-enabled PSS.5. Evolutionary Process Framework:¬†The research presents a process framework detailing the three phases of transformation (preparing, conceptualizing, industrializing) and shows how managerial practices and AI-enabled PSS evolve and interact throughout this journey.6. Theoretical Contributions:¬†The study advances the digital servitization literature by incorporating AI into PSS frameworks, defining specific managerial practices for AI implementation, and outlining a path model critical for manufacturers moving towards autonomous solutions.Many thanks to my great co-authors, Thomas Brekke, Rimsha Naeem, David Sj√∂din, and Vinit Parida, for co-creating this piece. Also, many thanks to the reviewers, special Issue editors, and International Journal of Production Economics.hashtag#ArtificialIntelligence hashtag#AI hashtag#servitization hashtag#servitization hashtag#PSS hashtag#BusinessModel hashtag#AutonomousSolutionsUniversity of Vaasa Strategic Business Development Research Group (SBD), University of Vaasa

Diving Deep into OpenThread Architecture for¬†STM32WB

"Yes, I still program in C when necessary. Why? Speed. And because it talks natively to the OS."Let me explain with a real-world example:I recently built a real-time WebSocket server to act as a multiplexer for users across multiple connections‚Äîsimilar to how WhatsApp syncs messages between your phone and desktop browser in real-time.‚úÖ When a message is sent or received, it broadcasts instantly to all connected devices.‚úÖ But the challenge? The core project was in PHP‚Äîand I needed real-time messaging without switching stacks.I tried PHP CLI to build the server, but hit a wall:‚Ä¢ No official multithreading support‚Ä¢ I had to rely on fork()‚Äîwhich creates a new process (slow & resource-heavy)‚Ä¢ And worse: sockets couldn‚Äôt be shared across processesHere‚Äôs the problem:Imagine your phone is connected on Process A, your laptop on Process B.When a message arrives for your phone, Process A can‚Äôt access Process B‚Äôs socket to forward it.That‚Äôs when I turned to C.With C:‚Ä¢ I implemented threads (sharing resources within a single process)‚Ä¢ The socket file descriptors remained accessible across threads‚Ä¢ I could handle each connection in its own thread, linked to the authenticated userHow? üëâ I implemented the RFC 6455 WebSocket spec for the handshake üëâ Then authenticated each connection by calling back to the PHP app (using the HTTP cookie) üëâ PHP responded with a success status and user ID, which I used to track connectionsThe result: a blazing fast, multi-threaded WebSocket server written in C, integrated seamlessly with PHP.In my next post, I‚Äôll cover how I used IPC to connect C and PHP, and how I grouped connections in a hashmap + linked list for efficient broadcasting.üëâ Curious about the challenges of mixing C and PHP in real-time systems? Let‚Äôs talk‚Äîdrop your questions below!hashtag#SystemDesign hashtag#PHP hashtag#C hashtag#Linux hashtag#WebSocket

Working with watchdog timers in RTOS systems brings interesting challenges.The basic idea is simple: the watchdog counts down and resets the system if it‚Äôs not reloaded in time useful to detect infinite loops or system hangs.But in multitask systems with different deadlines (e.g., one task running every 10ms, another every 100ms), feeding the watchdog from each task becomes unreliable and messy (due to timing and concurrency issues).Some alternatives I‚Äôve explored: - Idle-priority task feeding: Since the feeder task has the lowest priority, if any higher-priority task hangs, the watchdog won‚Äôt be fed and will eventually reset the system. - Task notification system: Each task sends an ‚ÄúI‚Äôm alive‚Äù signal to a watchdog monitor. If one fails, you can react more precisely, like restart only the faulty task if a full system reset isn‚Äôt necessary.While reading the hashtag#ZephyrRTOS docs, i've found a great solution called Task Watchdog:It uses kernel software timers to monitor tasks and can trigger custom callback functions when a task fails to reset its own timer. We can define per-task deadlines and recovery behavior, and still fall back to the hardware watchdog if needed.I might try this feature in my Zephyr-based cruise control system if I get the time, and if so, I‚Äôll share some of the results.

Force Majeure: Back-to-Back relevanceIn interconnected contracts, especially where you (as seller) are the intermediary, mismatched Force Majeure ("FM") clauses can leave you exposed. If your supplier is excused from performance due to an FM event, but your contract with the buyer doesn‚Äôt recognise the same event or relief, you could be held liable. The same applies if your buyer is excused from performance due to an FM event, but your contract with the seller does not recognise the same event. Why Back-to-Back FM Clauses Are Essential: 1. Risk Transfer Protection:‚Ä¢ If a supplier invokes FM to delay or cancel delivery, the seller must also have the right to invoke FM with the buyer.‚Ä¢ Without a back-to-back clause, the intermediary could still be liable to the buyer despite being unable to receive the goods from the supplier.Please note, this could apply similarly where the buyer invokes an FM event, where the intermediary would be liable to the supplier.2. Consistency in Legal Relief‚Ä¢ Ensures both contracts excuse performance for the same types of unforeseen events (e.g., war, natural disasters, strikes).‚Ä¢ Misalignment could result in one party being relieved while the other remains legally bound.3. Avoiding Commercial Gaps‚Ä¢ For example, if the purchase contract includes pandemics as an FM event but the sale contract does not, the intermediary could be stuck with an unfulfillable obligation and no legal shield.4. Aligned Notice Requirements‚Ä¢ Both contracts should include the same timing and method for notifying FM events.‚Ä¢ If the supplier has 48 hours to notify but the buyer requires notice within 24 hours, the intermediary could lose the right to claim FM downstream.5. Termination Triggers‚Ä¢ Many contracts allow termination if the FM persists beyond a certain period (e.g., 30 days).‚Ä¢ Back-to-back durations are essential to avoid mismatched termination rights and prevent being forced into or out of a deal unfairly.Example:A trader buys steel coils from a mill in China under a contract with an FM clause that includes ‚Äúnatural disasters.‚Äù He sells to a European buyer under a contract without an FM clause, or without the FM clause including natural disasters as an FM event. If Chinese ports close due to an earthquake:‚Ä¢ The supplier is excused from delivery.‚Ä¢ The trader is still bound to deliver to the buyer or pay damages‚Äîunless the FM clause is mirrored.Conclusion:In trading and supply chain transactions, back-to-back Force Majeure clauses are not just legal formalities or boilerplate‚Äîthey‚Äôre critical risk management tools. They ensure that when one party is excused from performance, the intermediary is not left exposed to penalties, claims, or losses from the other party.

Java 24 just dropped, and I took some of my saturday to dig into the changes compared to Java 23... And I have to say, it‚Äôs a solid update. One of the things I was really looking forward to was the finalization of the Foreign Function & Memory API, it basically gives Java a safe, high-performance way to interact with native code and memory, without all the clunky, error creator boilerplate of JNI. You can now allocate off-heap memory, call native libraries, and work with memory segments almost like you're in C, but with Java safety.. I also appreciate how Java 24 is going fr preview features, like unnamed variables and patterns, not sure if they are really usefull, but I like previews, lets test it.On the tooling and performance side, the improvements to the JIT compiler and the enhancements to garbage collection are things I started seeing the impact in some memory-heavy workloads. It feels like Java is becoming a more modern language without losing what made it so stable and reliable in the first place. I‚Äôm still cautious about adopting preview features in production, but I like where things are going, it‚Äôs like Java is shaking off some of its old weight while staying rock-solid for enterprise apps. I‚Äôll definitely be using Java 24 for side projects just to explore everything more deeply.Oh, almost forgot to mention, if you wanna test the previews, use this:--enable-preview If you‚Äôre using intelij, like me, you‚Äôll also need to enable preview features in the project settings.

DPDK, eBPF, and XDP: Their Crucial Roles in Virtual NetworkingIn virtual networking, DPDK, eBPF, and XDP each offer distinct advantages for optimizing performance, security, and observability. DPDK excels in high-performance, low-latency packet processing by bypassing the kernel, making it ideal for user-space network functions like virtual switches (OVS-DPDK) and virtual network functions (VNFs), where throughput and customizability are critical. eBPF, running in the kernel, enables efficient network observability, security policy enforcement, and deep packet inspection with minimal overhead. It is often integrated into Kubernetes CNI plugins like Cilium and Calico for network visibility and microsegmentation. XDP, built on top of eBPF, provides ultra-fast ingress filtering by executing programs directly at the NIC driver level, making it ideal for early packet filtering and load balancing, which reduces network congestion and latency in multi-tenant environments. Together, these technologies power modern cloud-native networks, providing high performance, flexible security, and granular control, particularly in virtualized environments like Kubernetes and NFV architectures.1. DPDKIdeal for virtual switches, VNFs, and edge compute gateways.Enables performance similar to hardware appliances.Extensively used in OpenStack and telecom NFV solutions.2. eBPF Powers Cilium, Tetragon, and other Kubernetes CNIs and observability tools.Integrates with Linux namespaces, cgroups, containers, and VMs.Extensible without kernel patches, supporting zero-trust security models.Limited performance vs DPDK in raw throughput.3. XDFIdeal for DDOS mitigation, early firewalling, and L4 load balancing.Reduces load on host networking stack yet important in multi-tenant environments.Limited programmability compared to full eBPF (no loops, tight instruction budget).Widely used in Cilium, Facebook Katran, and cloud CNI pipelines.hashtag#DPDK hashtag#eBPF hashtag#XDP hashtag#Cilium hashtag#Katran hashtag#CNI hashtag#Kubernetes hashtag#Tetragon hashtag#OVS

üöÄ Excited to share my latest serverless project!I built a fully serverless contact form system using AWS Lambda, API Gateway, DynamoDB and SNS, eliminating the need for server management while embracing a scalable and efficient architecture.Here‚Äôs how it works:API Gateway handles form submissionsAWS Lambda processes the logic (Python)DynamoDB stores the form dataSNS sends real-time admin alertsCORS headers enable smooth frontend integrationIAM roles ensure secure, least-privilege accessThis project gave me the opportunity to build a flexible, secure, and easily scalable solution using serverless principles.What i learned: * The power of API Gateway in routing and handling form submissions with    ease: API Gateway plays a pivotal role in the entire serverless flow. It handles HTTP requests and routes them to the correct AWS Lambda function, ensuring smooth communication between the frontend and backend. This makes it an essential tool for any serverless application, as it takes care of all the necessary HTTP request and response operations without requiring traditional server management.* How Lambda can simplify backend logic without managing traditional servers:AWS Lambda enables you to run code in response to events without the need to provision or manage servers. In this project, I leveraged Lambda to handle form submissions, which allowed me to focus solely on the logic (written in Python) without worrying about underlying infrastructure. This means no need for instance scaling or server maintenance‚ÄîLambda takes care of the scaling automatically based on the number of requests, making it a powerful tool for lightweight, cost-effective solutions.* The importance of setting up CORS headers properly for seamless integration with frontend applications: Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) is a crucial part of enabling smooth communication between a frontend (e.g., a web application) and a backend API hosted on a different domain. In this project, setting up CORS headers correctly allowed my frontend to make secure and successful API requests to the Lambda functions behind API Gateway. Without proper CORS configuration, you‚Äôd run into errors that would block requests, making the integration process a challenge. Handling CORS properly is essential for serverless architectures to work seamlessly across different domains.üìù Check out the full project walkthrough here:

Is "Consideration" still relevant in Modern Contract Law?ü§î" ÿßŸÑÿπŸÇŸàÿØ ÿßŸÑÿπŸàÿ∂Ÿäÿ© "üëáüèªüëáüèªüëáüèªIn an age of digital transactions, subscription models, and smart contracts, some might wonder: does the Doctrine of Consideration still matter?‚ÅâÔ∏è‚ùì‚ùì‚ùìThe answer is yes ‚úîÔ∏è... and here's why:üëáüèª‚è© The Doctrine of "Consideration" ensures that a contract reflects a mutual exchange. It's not just about promises, it's about value. Whether it's payment for a service, access to software, or even agreeing to refrain from a certain action, consideration creates the legal backbone that makes the agreement enforceable.‚è© Modern contracts may look different such as Clickwrap agreements, Software as a Service (SaaS), and Influencer Brand Deals, but the principle remains: no "Consideration", no binding contract.‚è© Even in jurisdictions exploring contract reform, the idea that both parties must give something to get something remains a key safeguard against unfair or one-sided obligations.‚è© Understanding "Consideration" is essential for legal professionals, founders, and anyone involved in "deal-making" in the digital economy.üé¨ What are your thoughts on how technology is changing the way we handle contracts‚ùì hashtag#ContractLaw hashtag#LegalTech hashtag#DigitalContracts hashtag#ModernLaw hashtag#TechAndLaw hashtag#StartupLaw hashtag#SaaSContracts hashtag#BusinessLaw hashtag#Consideration hashtag#LegalBasicshashtag#ÿßŸÑŸÇÿßŸÜŸàŸÜ hashtag#ÿßŸÑÿπŸÇŸàÿØ hashtag#ÿßŸÑŸÇÿßŸÜŸàŸÜ_ÿßŸÑŸÖÿØŸÜŸä hashtag#ÿßŸÑŸÇÿßŸÜŸàŸÜ_ÿßŸÑÿ™ÿ¨ÿßÿ±Ÿä hashtag#ÿßŸÑÿ™ÿ≠ŸàŸÑ_ÿßŸÑÿ±ŸÇŸÖŸä hashtag#ÿπŸÇŸàÿØ_ÿπŸàÿ∂Ÿäÿ© hashtag#ÿßŸÑÿ∞ŸÉÿßÿ°_ÿßŸÑÿßÿµÿ∑ŸÜÿßÿπŸä_ŸàÿßŸÑŸÇÿßŸÜŸàŸÜ hashtag#ÿ±ŸäÿßÿØÿ©_ÿßŸÑÿ£ÿπŸÖÿßŸÑ_ÿßŸÑŸÇÿßŸÜŸàŸÜŸäÿ© hashtag#ÿßŸÑÿπŸÖŸÑ_ÿßŸÑŸÇÿßŸÜŸàŸÜŸä hashtag#ÿßŸÑŸÇÿßŸÜŸàŸÜ_ŸàÿßŸÑÿ™ŸÉŸÜŸàŸÑŸàÿ¨Ÿäÿßÿ™_ÿßŸÑÿ≠ÿØŸäÿ´ÿ©

A Note to my Fellow General Counsels: Protect Your Business First.I‚Äôve been reviewing a lot of agreements lately and i thought to share this:When reviewing legal agreements, always begin with the end in mind. Assume realistically, that the relationship may deteriorate. Your role is to ensure your organisation is insulated when it does.One of the most critical tools in your arsenal? The termination clause.Scrutinise it. Then scrutinise the clauses that hinge on it; notice periods, payment obligations, survival provisions, dispute mechanisms. These are not boilerplate. They are strategy. Spin it in all ways till you are comfortable with the way it sounds should the relationship breakdown. Insist on the right to terminate without cause. Say it clearly: ‚ÄúWe reserve the right to terminate this agreement at any time, without cause, by providing a 5-day written notice.‚Äù Nothing about your termination clause should be ambiguous or interpreted in a way that can give rise to a different meaning but that which you intended. Any attempt by the counterparty to dilute or eliminate this right should be met with resistance, or at minimum, renegotiated with leverage. If you‚Äôre the party with power, exercise it. If you‚Äôre not, structure flexibility into the agreement early.Termination without cause is not just a fallback. It‚Äôs your legal parachute.ü™Çhashtag#GeneralCounsel hashtag#LegalLeadership hashtag#ExecutiveLeadership.

üß† Deep Dive: From Notification Failure to Protocol Insight ‚Äì Debugging SCTP_SEND_FAILEDIn this post, I walk through a subtle but critical SCTP issue that emerged when handling SCTP_SEND_FAILED notifications ‚Äî exploring how low-level socket events, memory layout, and system-generated notification structures like sctp_send_failed reveal the real root cause behind failed datagram delivery in production.üîç Unpacking SCTP_SEND_FAILED: From Kernel Notification to Root CauseIn SCTP-based communication systems, handling failure gracefully is as critical as achieving successful transmission. This post traces a real-world debugging session triggered by a recurring SCTP_SEND_FAILED notification ‚Äî often dismissed as a low-level socket error, but here unpacked layer by layer to reveal deep transport-level insights.We begin at the point of failure: a datagram silently dropped, triggering a structured SCTP notification. Using sctp_send_failed and its fields (ssf_type, ssf_flags, ssf_error, and ssf_info), we decode the kernel's message about why the send operation couldn't complete. We show how to safely extract this information from a raw notification buffer, interpret the semantics of each field, and map it back to application-layer intent.To go deeper, we captured traffic with Wireshark and discovered a critical clue: a heartbeat message sent from a Docker container to our system, which unexpectedly led to the abortion of the SCTP association. This insight helped correlate the SCTP_SEND_FAILED with external traffic patterns, uncovering the real trigger ‚Äî an out-of-band heartbeat interpreted as a protocol violation or arriving during a teardown state.By analyzing memory handling, buffer reuse, and edge-case protocol behavior (like full receive queues or association termination), we arrived at a concrete cause ‚Äî often buried deep beneath user-facing symptoms. This is a story of system-level observability, correct struct alignment, and mastering the contract between user space and kernel through precise data interpretation.Ideal for engineers working with SCTP, E2AP, or any protocol stack that depends on robust notification handling.I‚Äôd be glad to collaborate on any projects in the fields of telecommunications systems, wireless networks, network protocols, or low-level programming. If you believe my experience and skills can contribute to your work, I‚Äôd be more than happy to be part of your team ‚Äî even in a small role.

Introducing Wizzy ‚Äî a surveillance and patrolling robot I developed as part of my Tinker Lab project, designed to work in environments where traditional CCTV systems fall short.Wizzy is more than just a mobile bot. It‚Äôs a self-thinking, self-correcting system powered by a Raspberry Pi 4 ‚Äî capable of intelligent patrolling, real-time decision-making, and remote monitoring. Built with flexibility and scalability in mind, Wizzy is ideal for warehouses, mid-sized factories, or secure zones where both movement and memory matter.What makes Wizzy tick:1) Smart Patrol System: Avoids getting stuck, detects patterns, and makes decisions based on sensor input2) Memory of previous states and paths: Reduces repeated loops and improves efficiency over time3) Remote Surveillance: Includes a web dashboard for manual control and camera feed access4) Real-time camera monitoring: Captures and transmits visual data during patrol5) Modular codebase: Clean Python code with multithreading and behavior modelingUnder the hood: Wizzy‚Äôs core logic is written in Python, using multithreading for non-blocking patrol control. The SmartPatrol engine implements a stateful decision system ‚Äî analyzing IR sensor inputs to detect obstacles, identify stuck loops, and dynamically choose optimal turn directions. It uses pattern history (via deques), state memory, and an adaptive escape mechanism to enhance area coverage. Motion control, decision branches, and environmental feedback are abstracted for flexibility and reusability.The entire project is open-source and available here: üîó https://lnkd.in/dY4KyM3BThis started as a college submission ‚Äî but I see it as the first step toward practical, deployable surveillance robotics.hashtag#Robotics hashtag#Automation hashtag#Surveillance hashtag#RaspberryPi hashtag#PythonProjects hashtag#CollegeProjects hashtag#SmartSecurity hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#WizzyBot hashtag#OpenSource

Here's my latest JavaFX project. The famous card game locally known as 'Daketti'.After often playing with friends till late night, I thought why not code it?Here's are its main features‚û°Ô∏èPlayed between four players with two in each team.‚û°Ô∏èGame starts with 4 cards in hand of each player and 4 cards in center.‚û°Ô∏èExcessive use of List and Stack data structures.‚û°Ô∏èJavaFX Transition classes for animation.‚û°Ô∏èUse of OOP principles for a scalable structure.‚û°Ô∏èGame result calculation in the end.Currently it is played on a single PC. Future plans are to make it playable on LAN on 4 PC's using java socket programming. Also the code design focuses on all 4 OOP principles, so I have a plan to add some other card games in the collection like (local names) 'Thula', 'Bluff', etc.

Well-designed APIs behave consistently, fair predictably, and grow without friction. Some best practices to keep in mind are as follows:1 - Resource-oriented paths and proper use of HTTP verbs help APIs align with standard tools.2 - Use a proper API versioning approach.3 - Use standard error codes while generating API responses.4 - APIs should be idempotent. They ensure safe retries by making repeated requests to produce the same result, especially for POST operations.5 - Idempotency keys allow clients to safely deduplicate operations with side effects.6 - APIs should support pagination to prevent performance bottlenecks and payload bloat. Some common pagination strategies are offset-based, cursor-based, and keyset-based.7 - API security is mandatory for well-designed APIs. Use proper authentication and authorization with APIs using API Keys, JWTs, OAuth2, and other mechanisms. HTTPS is also a must-have for APIs running in production.

Ouzo-Driven Innovation: Rethinking Transformation on the Shores of Crete(Long Polish May weekend parody post ;) )As global leaders debate AI ethics and supply chain resilience, a quiet but powerful shift is happening under the Mediterranean sun. Here on Crete, I‚Äôve spent the last few days deep-diving into a radically decentralized, ouzo-fueled innovation ecosystem ‚Äî and the insights are staggering.This island isn‚Äôt just a vacation spot. It‚Äôs a next-gen sandbox for sun-powered cognitive agility. Every taverna is a use case. Every glass of ouzo? A local MVP (Minimum Viable Productivity).Key takeaways from the Cretan Tech Stack:‚û°Ô∏èLiquid-Led Ideation: Traditional brainstorming is out. ‚ÄúOuzoStorming‚Ñ¢‚Äù encourages asynchronous ideation supported by grilled squid and ambient goat sounds.‚û°Ô∏èDecentralized Agility: Herding cats? Try herding donkeys through olive groves. The agile metaphor is alive and braying.‚û°Ô∏èZorba-as-a-Service (ZaaS): Local dance-based leadership rituals now drive team cohesion and real-time alignment, measured in BPM (Beats per Minute).‚û°Ô∏èRelax-to-Earn Infrastructure: Blockchain-enhanced beach chairs allow for staking your towel and generating ‚ÄúPassive Leisure Yield.‚Äù Optional NFT upgrade includes a frappe.‚û°Ô∏èEmbedded UX Rituals: Every strategic lunch concludes with unsolicited raki and dessert ‚Äî a UX feature that transforms customer journeys into literal sugar rushes.‚û°Ô∏èAmbient Feline Monitoring (AFM): Strategic feline deployment (i.e. street cats) ensures continuous surveillance of sidewalk sentiment and supports natural pest control in legacy systems.‚û°Ô∏èWisdom-as-a-Platform (WaaP): Elderly Greek men form decentralized knowledge hubs (a.k.a. kafeneio clusters), delivering continuous, unfiltered socio-political commentary in analog format, with optional smoke signal outputs.‚û°Ô∏èFarm-to-Framework Cuisine: Local KPIs include ‚ÄúDaily Freshness Index,‚Äù measured in tomato juiciness and feta salinity. Culinary ops are lean, green, and olive-oil optimized.Crete isn‚Äôt just following trends ‚Äî it‚Äôs disrupting disruption itself. For anyone in BSS, FDI, AI, ESG, DEI, BYOB or just REST ‚Äî this island is a must-watch.More insights to follow...after my next raki.hashtag#crete hashtag#greece hashtag#weekend hashtag#parody

hashtag#Day11_of_learning with BOLUWATIFE ASOKERE Day 11 was all about understanding how to structure API requests. Here‚Äôs a clear breakdown of what I learned:1. API Endpoint  This is the main URL where the request is sent. It follows the format: `baseURL/Endpoint` (e.g.http://api.example.com/users).2. Path Parameters These are used to specify a particular resource. The format is: `baseURL/Endpoint/{path-parameter}` (e.g., https://api.example.comq/users/123). For example, "123" identifies a specific user.3. Query Parameters These are used to filter or sort data. The format is: `baseURL/Endpoint?query=value` hashtag#30days_of_learninghashtag#APIs

Our newest study on "Managerial practices shaping the transformation towards artificial intelligence-enabled product‚Äìservice systems" is out as hashtag#OpenAccessSome highlights:1. Focus on Digital Servitization and AI:¬†The research highlights the significance of digital service innovation within manufacturing and the need to understand the pathways for transitioning to AI-enabled PSS, given the rapid advancement of AI technologies.2. Identification of Managerial Practices:¬†the study investigates and identifies essential managerial practices, such as strategizing, evangelizing, and routinizing, required during different phases (preparing, conceptualizing, industrializing) of the transformation towards AI-enabled PSS, utilizing practice theory.3. Development of a Multi-Layered Path Model:¬†The study proposes a model illustrating the interconnectedness of AI-enabled PSS, the associated technologies, and crucial ecosystem partnerships needed for a successful transformation.4. Key Case Study Insights:¬†Findings from a case study emphasize the critical need for developing a robust digital infrastructure, integrating established system technologies, industrializing AI capabilities, and fostering ecosystem partnerships to create effective AI-enabled PSS.5. Evolutionary Process Framework:¬†The research presents a process framework detailing the three phases of transformation (preparing, conceptualizing, industrializing) and shows how managerial practices and AI-enabled PSS evolve and interact throughout this journey.6. Theoretical Contributions:¬†The study advances the digital servitization literature by incorporating AI into PSS frameworks, defining specific managerial practices for AI implementation, and outlining a path model critical for manufacturers moving towards autonomous solutions.Many thanks to my great co-authors, Thomas Brekke, Rimsha Naeem, David Sj√∂din, and Vinit Parida, for co-creating this piece. Also, many thanks to the reviewers, special Issue editors, and International Journal of Production Economics.hashtag#ArtificialIntelligence hashtag#AI hashtag#servitization hashtag#servitization hashtag#PSS hashtag#BusinessModel hashtag#AutonomousSolutionsUniversity of Vaasa Strategic Business Development Research Group (SBD), University of Vaasa

Diving Deep into OpenThread Architecture for¬†STM32WB

"Yes, I still program in C when necessary. Why? Speed. And because it talks natively to the OS."Let me explain with a real-world example:I recently built a real-time WebSocket server to act as a multiplexer for users across multiple connections‚Äîsimilar to how WhatsApp syncs messages between your phone and desktop browser in real-time.‚úÖ When a message is sent or received, it broadcasts instantly to all connected devices.‚úÖ But the challenge? The core project was in PHP‚Äîand I needed real-time messaging without switching stacks.I tried PHP CLI to build the server, but hit a wall:‚Ä¢ No official multithreading support‚Ä¢ I had to rely on fork()‚Äîwhich creates a new process (slow & resource-heavy)‚Ä¢ And worse: sockets couldn‚Äôt be shared across processesHere‚Äôs the problem:Imagine your phone is connected on Process A, your laptop on Process B.When a message arrives for your phone, Process A can‚Äôt access Process B‚Äôs socket to forward it.That‚Äôs when I turned to C.With C:‚Ä¢ I implemented threads (sharing resources within a single process)‚Ä¢ The socket file descriptors remained accessible across threads‚Ä¢ I could handle each connection in its own thread, linked to the authenticated userHow? üëâ I implemented the RFC 6455 WebSocket spec for the handshake üëâ Then authenticated each connection by calling back to the PHP app (using the HTTP cookie) üëâ PHP responded with a success status and user ID, which I used to track connectionsThe result: a blazing fast, multi-threaded WebSocket server written in C, integrated seamlessly with PHP.In my next post, I‚Äôll cover how I used IPC to connect C and PHP, and how I grouped connections in a hashmap + linked list for efficient broadcasting.üëâ Curious about the challenges of mixing C and PHP in real-time systems? Let‚Äôs talk‚Äîdrop your questions below!hashtag#SystemDesign hashtag#PHP hashtag#C hashtag#Linux hashtag#WebSocket

Working with watchdog timers in RTOS systems brings interesting challenges.The basic idea is simple: the watchdog counts down and resets the system if it‚Äôs not reloaded in time useful to detect infinite loops or system hangs.But in multitask systems with different deadlines (e.g., one task running every 10ms, another every 100ms), feeding the watchdog from each task becomes unreliable and messy (due to timing and concurrency issues).Some alternatives I‚Äôve explored: - Idle-priority task feeding: Since the feeder task has the lowest priority, if any higher-priority task hangs, the watchdog won‚Äôt be fed and will eventually reset the system. - Task notification system: Each task sends an ‚ÄúI‚Äôm alive‚Äù signal to a watchdog monitor. If one fails, you can react more precisely, like restart only the faulty task if a full system reset isn‚Äôt necessary.While reading the hashtag#ZephyrRTOS docs, i've found a great solution called Task Watchdog:It uses kernel software timers to monitor tasks and can trigger custom callback functions when a task fails to reset its own timer. We can define per-task deadlines and recovery behavior, and still fall back to the hardware watchdog if needed.I might try this feature in my Zephyr-based cruise control system if I get the time, and if so, I‚Äôll share some of the results.

Force Majeure: Back-to-Back relevanceIn interconnected contracts, especially where you (as seller) are the intermediary, mismatched Force Majeure ("FM") clauses can leave you exposed. If your supplier is excused from performance due to an FM event, but your contract with the buyer doesn‚Äôt recognise the same event or relief, you could be held liable. The same applies if your buyer is excused from performance due to an FM event, but your contract with the seller does not recognise the same event. Why Back-to-Back FM Clauses Are Essential: 1. Risk Transfer Protection:‚Ä¢ If a supplier invokes FM to delay or cancel delivery, the seller must also have the right to invoke FM with the buyer.‚Ä¢ Without a back-to-back clause, the intermediary could still be liable to the buyer despite being unable to receive the goods from the supplier.Please note, this could apply similarly where the buyer invokes an FM event, where the intermediary would be liable to the supplier.2. Consistency in Legal Relief‚Ä¢ Ensures both contracts excuse performance for the same types of unforeseen events (e.g., war, natural disasters, strikes).‚Ä¢ Misalignment could result in one party being relieved while the other remains legally bound.3. Avoiding Commercial Gaps‚Ä¢ For example, if the purchase contract includes pandemics as an FM event but the sale contract does not, the intermediary could be stuck with an unfulfillable obligation and no legal shield.4. Aligned Notice Requirements‚Ä¢ Both contracts should include the same timing and method for notifying FM events.‚Ä¢ If the supplier has 48 hours to notify but the buyer requires notice within 24 hours, the intermediary could lose the right to claim FM downstream.5. Termination Triggers‚Ä¢ Many contracts allow termination if the FM persists beyond a certain period (e.g., 30 days).‚Ä¢ Back-to-back durations are essential to avoid mismatched termination rights and prevent being forced into or out of a deal unfairly.Example:A trader buys steel coils from a mill in China under a contract with an FM clause that includes ‚Äúnatural disasters.‚Äù He sells to a European buyer under a contract without an FM clause, or without the FM clause including natural disasters as an FM event. If Chinese ports close due to an earthquake:‚Ä¢ The supplier is excused from delivery.‚Ä¢ The trader is still bound to deliver to the buyer or pay damages‚Äîunless the FM clause is mirrored.Conclusion:In trading and supply chain transactions, back-to-back Force Majeure clauses are not just legal formalities or boilerplate‚Äîthey‚Äôre critical risk management tools. They ensure that when one party is excused from performance, the intermediary is not left exposed to penalties, claims, or losses from the other party.

Java 24 just dropped, and I took some of my saturday to dig into the changes compared to Java 23... And I have to say, it‚Äôs a solid update. One of the things I was really looking forward to was the finalization of the Foreign Function & Memory API, it basically gives Java a safe, high-performance way to interact with native code and memory, without all the clunky, error creator boilerplate of JNI. You can now allocate off-heap memory, call native libraries, and work with memory segments almost like you're in C, but with Java safety.. I also appreciate how Java 24 is going fr preview features, like unnamed variables and patterns, not sure if they are really usefull, but I like previews, lets test it.On the tooling and performance side, the improvements to the JIT compiler and the enhancements to garbage collection are things I started seeing the impact in some memory-heavy workloads. It feels like Java is becoming a more modern language without losing what made it so stable and reliable in the first place. I‚Äôm still cautious about adopting preview features in production, but I like where things are going, it‚Äôs like Java is shaking off some of its old weight while staying rock-solid for enterprise apps. I‚Äôll definitely be using Java 24 for side projects just to explore everything more deeply.Oh, almost forgot to mention, if you wanna test the previews, use this:--enable-preview If you‚Äôre using intelij, like me, you‚Äôll also need to enable preview features in the project settings.

DPDK, eBPF, and XDP: Their Crucial Roles in Virtual NetworkingIn virtual networking, DPDK, eBPF, and XDP each offer distinct advantages for optimizing performance, security, and observability. DPDK excels in high-performance, low-latency packet processing by bypassing the kernel, making it ideal for user-space network functions like virtual switches (OVS-DPDK) and virtual network functions (VNFs), where throughput and customizability are critical. eBPF, running in the kernel, enables efficient network observability, security policy enforcement, and deep packet inspection with minimal overhead. It is often integrated into Kubernetes CNI plugins like Cilium and Calico for network visibility and microsegmentation. XDP, built on top of eBPF, provides ultra-fast ingress filtering by executing programs directly at the NIC driver level, making it ideal for early packet filtering and load balancing, which reduces network congestion and latency in multi-tenant environments. Together, these technologies power modern cloud-native networks, providing high performance, flexible security, and granular control, particularly in virtualized environments like Kubernetes and NFV architectures.1. DPDKIdeal for virtual switches, VNFs, and edge compute gateways.Enables performance similar to hardware appliances.Extensively used in OpenStack and telecom NFV solutions.2. eBPF Powers Cilium, Tetragon, and other Kubernetes CNIs and observability tools.Integrates with Linux namespaces, cgroups, containers, and VMs.Extensible without kernel patches, supporting zero-trust security models.Limited performance vs DPDK in raw throughput.3. XDFIdeal for DDOS mitigation, early firewalling, and L4 load balancing.Reduces load on host networking stack yet important in multi-tenant environments.Limited programmability compared to full eBPF (no loops, tight instruction budget).Widely used in Cilium, Facebook Katran, and cloud CNI pipelines.hashtag#DPDK hashtag#eBPF hashtag#XDP hashtag#Cilium hashtag#Katran hashtag#CNI hashtag#Kubernetes hashtag#Tetragon hashtag#OVS

üöÄ Excited to share my latest serverless project!I built a fully serverless contact form system using AWS Lambda, API Gateway, DynamoDB and SNS, eliminating the need for server management while embracing a scalable and efficient architecture.Here‚Äôs how it works:API Gateway handles form submissionsAWS Lambda processes the logic (Python)DynamoDB stores the form dataSNS sends real-time admin alertsCORS headers enable smooth frontend integrationIAM roles ensure secure, least-privilege accessThis project gave me the opportunity to build a flexible, secure, and easily scalable solution using serverless principles.What i learned: * The power of API Gateway in routing and handling form submissions with    ease: API Gateway plays a pivotal role in the entire serverless flow. It handles HTTP requests and routes them to the correct AWS Lambda function, ensuring smooth communication between the frontend and backend. This makes it an essential tool for any serverless application, as it takes care of all the necessary HTTP request and response operations without requiring traditional server management.* How Lambda can simplify backend logic without managing traditional servers:AWS Lambda enables you to run code in response to events without the need to provision or manage servers. In this project, I leveraged Lambda to handle form submissions, which allowed me to focus solely on the logic (written in Python) without worrying about underlying infrastructure. This means no need for instance scaling or server maintenance‚ÄîLambda takes care of the scaling automatically based on the number of requests, making it a powerful tool for lightweight, cost-effective solutions.* The importance of setting up CORS headers properly for seamless integration with frontend applications: Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) is a crucial part of enabling smooth communication between a frontend (e.g., a web application) and a backend API hosted on a different domain. In this project, setting up CORS headers correctly allowed my frontend to make secure and successful API requests to the Lambda functions behind API Gateway. Without proper CORS configuration, you‚Äôd run into errors that would block requests, making the integration process a challenge. Handling CORS properly is essential for serverless architectures to work seamlessly across different domains.üìù Check out the full project walkthrough here:

Is "Consideration" still relevant in Modern Contract Law?ü§î" ÿßŸÑÿπŸÇŸàÿØ ÿßŸÑÿπŸàÿ∂Ÿäÿ© "üëáüèªüëáüèªüëáüèªIn an age of digital transactions, subscription models, and smart contracts, some might wonder: does the Doctrine of Consideration still matter?‚ÅâÔ∏è‚ùì‚ùì‚ùìThe answer is yes ‚úîÔ∏è... and here's why:üëáüèª‚è© The Doctrine of "Consideration" ensures that a contract reflects a mutual exchange. It's not just about promises, it's about value. Whether it's payment for a service, access to software, or even agreeing to refrain from a certain action, consideration creates the legal backbone that makes the agreement enforceable.‚è© Modern contracts may look different such as Clickwrap agreements, Software as a Service (SaaS), and Influencer Brand Deals, but the principle remains: no "Consideration", no binding contract.‚è© Even in jurisdictions exploring contract reform, the idea that both parties must give something to get something remains a key safeguard against unfair or one-sided obligations.‚è© Understanding "Consideration" is essential for legal professionals, founders, and anyone involved in "deal-making" in the digital economy.üé¨ What are your thoughts on how technology is changing the way we handle contracts‚ùì hashtag#ContractLaw hashtag#LegalTech hashtag#DigitalContracts hashtag#ModernLaw hashtag#TechAndLaw hashtag#StartupLaw hashtag#SaaSContracts hashtag#BusinessLaw hashtag#Consideration hashtag#LegalBasicshashtag#ÿßŸÑŸÇÿßŸÜŸàŸÜ hashtag#ÿßŸÑÿπŸÇŸàÿØ hashtag#ÿßŸÑŸÇÿßŸÜŸàŸÜ_ÿßŸÑŸÖÿØŸÜŸä hashtag#ÿßŸÑŸÇÿßŸÜŸàŸÜ_ÿßŸÑÿ™ÿ¨ÿßÿ±Ÿä hashtag#ÿßŸÑÿ™ÿ≠ŸàŸÑ_ÿßŸÑÿ±ŸÇŸÖŸä hashtag#ÿπŸÇŸàÿØ_ÿπŸàÿ∂Ÿäÿ© hashtag#ÿßŸÑÿ∞ŸÉÿßÿ°_ÿßŸÑÿßÿµÿ∑ŸÜÿßÿπŸä_ŸàÿßŸÑŸÇÿßŸÜŸàŸÜ hashtag#ÿ±ŸäÿßÿØÿ©_ÿßŸÑÿ£ÿπŸÖÿßŸÑ_ÿßŸÑŸÇÿßŸÜŸàŸÜŸäÿ© hashtag#ÿßŸÑÿπŸÖŸÑ_ÿßŸÑŸÇÿßŸÜŸàŸÜŸä hashtag#ÿßŸÑŸÇÿßŸÜŸàŸÜ_ŸàÿßŸÑÿ™ŸÉŸÜŸàŸÑŸàÿ¨Ÿäÿßÿ™_ÿßŸÑÿ≠ÿØŸäÿ´ÿ©

A Note to my Fellow General Counsels: Protect Your Business First.I‚Äôve been reviewing a lot of agreements lately and i thought to share this:When reviewing legal agreements, always begin with the end in mind. Assume realistically, that the relationship may deteriorate. Your role is to ensure your organisation is insulated when it does.One of the most critical tools in your arsenal? The termination clause.Scrutinise it. Then scrutinise the clauses that hinge on it; notice periods, payment obligations, survival provisions, dispute mechanisms. These are not boilerplate. They are strategy. Spin it in all ways till you are comfortable with the way it sounds should the relationship breakdown. Insist on the right to terminate without cause. Say it clearly: ‚ÄúWe reserve the right to terminate this agreement at any time, without cause, by providing a 5-day written notice.‚Äù Nothing about your termination clause should be ambiguous or interpreted in a way that can give rise to a different meaning but that which you intended. Any attempt by the counterparty to dilute or eliminate this right should be met with resistance, or at minimum, renegotiated with leverage. If you‚Äôre the party with power, exercise it. If you‚Äôre not, structure flexibility into the agreement early.Termination without cause is not just a fallback. It‚Äôs your legal parachute.ü™Çhashtag#GeneralCounsel hashtag#LegalLeadership hashtag#ExecutiveLeadership.

üß† Deep Dive: From Notification Failure to Protocol Insight ‚Äì Debugging SCTP_SEND_FAILEDIn this post, I walk through a subtle but critical SCTP issue that emerged when handling SCTP_SEND_FAILED notifications ‚Äî exploring how low-level socket events, memory layout, and system-generated notification structures like sctp_send_failed reveal the real root cause behind failed datagram delivery in production.üîç Unpacking SCTP_SEND_FAILED: From Kernel Notification to Root CauseIn SCTP-based communication systems, handling failure gracefully is as critical as achieving successful transmission. This post traces a real-world debugging session triggered by a recurring SCTP_SEND_FAILED notification ‚Äî often dismissed as a low-level socket error, but here unpacked layer by layer to reveal deep transport-level insights.We begin at the point of failure: a datagram silently dropped, triggering a structured SCTP notification. Using sctp_send_failed and its fields (ssf_type, ssf_flags, ssf_error, and ssf_info), we decode the kernel's message about why the send operation couldn't complete. We show how to safely extract this information from a raw notification buffer, interpret the semantics of each field, and map it back to application-layer intent.To go deeper, we captured traffic with Wireshark and discovered a critical clue: a heartbeat message sent from a Docker container to our system, which unexpectedly led to the abortion of the SCTP association. This insight helped correlate the SCTP_SEND_FAILED with external traffic patterns, uncovering the real trigger ‚Äî an out-of-band heartbeat interpreted as a protocol violation or arriving during a teardown state.By analyzing memory handling, buffer reuse, and edge-case protocol behavior (like full receive queues or association termination), we arrived at a concrete cause ‚Äî often buried deep beneath user-facing symptoms. This is a story of system-level observability, correct struct alignment, and mastering the contract between user space and kernel through precise data interpretation.Ideal for engineers working with SCTP, E2AP, or any protocol stack that depends on robust notification handling.I‚Äôd be glad to collaborate on any projects in the fields of telecommunications systems, wireless networks, network protocols, or low-level programming. If you believe my experience and skills can contribute to your work, I‚Äôd be more than happy to be part of your team ‚Äî even in a small role.
